message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Romanized terms kill the philosophical experiment">
The author raises a critical point about the "philosophical experiment" argument:

If we romanize everything — Dao, De, Ren, Yi, Li — then the passage has NO English semantic content for the Western reader. The reader encounters five opaque foreign terms in a sequence. The "philosophical experiment" (where the reader first accepts a conventional understanding, then watches it get deconstructed) CANNOT work, because the reader never had a conventional understanding to begin with. The romanized terms have very few morphisms in their Jing — they are semantically empty for the English reader.

The experiment requires the reader to FEEL something when they read "virtue," "humaneness," "righteousness" — to bring their own associations — and THEN experience the reversal. If they just see "De, Ren, Yi, Li," they have nothing to reverse. The passage becomes an abstract report about foreign concepts rather than a lived philosophical experience.

Does this change your thinking? Should we use English translations (the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, ritual conduct) in the block quote precisely SO the philosophical experiment works on the English reader?

Reconsider. Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
The author is right. This is a decisive argument and I had not thought it through properly.

The whole point of the passage is: you start with concepts you think you understand top-down (the Way generates virtue, virtue generates humaneness...), and then the author shows the entire hierarchy is actually constructed bottom-up from phenomena. The reversal is the philosophical payload. For this to work, the reader must *start with a loaded understanding* -- they must feel the weight of "virtue," "humaneness," "righteousness" as concepts with real content, so that the inversion is felt, not merely reported.

A reader who encounters "De, Ren, Yi, Li" starts with nothing. They cannot experience the reversal because they never held the original position. The passage becomes: "here is a sequence of foreign terms; now the author rearranges them." That is a description of a philosophical experiment, not a philosophical experiment.

This is exactly the principle our own Memo states: "experiential sequences are load-bearing" and "the form IS the method." I was applying this principle to the cat example and the Bob examples but failed to apply it here.

**Revised position:** Use full English throughout the block quote -- "the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, ritual conduct" -- with first-occurrence glosses per our convention. Use these same English terms in the author's analysis as well, EXCEPT for 德 which shifts to "(constitutive) character" at the transition point (as already decided). The English terms carry the semantic load that makes the reversal experienceable. The glosses (漢字, pinyin) provide the scholarly apparatus without interrupting the experience.

I withdraw my earlier preference for bare romanization in running text for this passage.
input.summary: Author is right — English terms needed for the experiment to work on the reader
